metadata.title: Effect of nano-size fumed silica on ionic conductivity of PVdF-HFP-based plasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes

sections.text: Keywords Nano-composite . Ammonium tetrafluoroborate . Conductivity . Plasticizer . Fumed silica

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The research on polymer electrolytes has started in early the 1970s with polyethylene oxide (PEO) polymer and alkali metal salts [1, 2], but their practical applications were highlighted in 1978 by Armand and co-workers [3]. Since then, research on solid polymer electrolytes has grown widely [4–6]. Polymer electrolytes have a number of advantages over the conventional liquid electrolytes, such as longer shelf life, freedom from corrosive liquid leakage, easy fabrication in a wide variety of shapes, ability to form proper electrode-electrolyte contacts, and chemical stability [7–9]. Most of the initial work has been carried out on lithium ion conducting polymer electrolytes [10, 11], but proton conducting polymer electrolytes based on polyethylene oxide (PEO) have also been extensively studied due to their potential applications in secondary batteries, sensors, electrochromic devices, fuel cells, etc. [8, 12–14]. Theoretical models for ion conduction in polymer electrolytes and nano-composite polymer electrolytes have extensively been studied by different authors [15–20]. As PEO is more crystalline polymer, so their electrolytes possess low ionic conductivity at room temperature, which limits their use in practical applications. The conductivity of polymer electrolytes can be increased by using such polymer which is amorphous in nature, like poly(vinylidene fluoride-cohexafluoropropylene) (PVdF-HFP) [21–24]. Many other approaches have also been adopted to enhance the conductivity of polymer electrolytes to a reasonable value suitable for their use in practical applications, which includes the use of salt with large anions, addition of plasticizers, and addition of inert insulating matrix of micro- and nano-size [8, 9, 14, 25–28, Sharma et al. 2016, Enhancement in mechanical and electrical properties of PVdF-HFP based plasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes, submitted]. Most of the studies on polymer electrolytes have been reported for (i) plasticized polymer * Shuchi Sharma sharmashuchi82@gmail.com 1 Department of Physics, Sri Sai University, Palampur, Himachal Pradesh 176 081, India 2 Department of Physics, Goswami Ganesh Dutt Sanatan Dharam College, Hariana, Hoshiarpur, Punjab 144 208, India
electrolytes in which the addition of plasticizers enhances the amorphous content, which is reported to be the high conducting phase along with lowering of glass transition temperature (Tg) and dissociation of ion aggregates/undissociated salt present at higher concentrations, and (ii) composite plasticized polymer electrolytes in which the addition of insulating matrix enhances the conductivity of polymer electrolytes along with an improvement in mechanical properties [8, 9, 14, 29–31].
In the present paper, PVdF-HFP, which is an amorphous polymer with dielectric constant (ε = 7.6), has been used to prepare polymer electrolytes and electrical properties of these electrolytes have been studied. The effect of addition of salt, plasticizer, and nano-size fumed silica on conductivity behavior of nano-composite polymer electrolytes has been studied. X-ray diffraction analysis of polymer electrolyte system was carried out. The variation of conductivity of plasticized nanocomposite polymer electrolytes as a function of temperature and time has also been studied.

sections.heading: Experimental details
sections.text: Poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVdFHFP) (FLUKAAv. Mol. Wt. = 130,000), ammonium tetrafluoroborate (NH4BF4) (Reidel), tetrahydrofuran (THF) (Merck), dimethylacetamide (DMA) (Merck), and fumed silica (Aldrich) with surface area 380 m2/g and average grain size 7 nmwere used as the startingmaterials. Films of polymer electrolytes were prepared by solution casting technique using tetrahydrofuran as a solvent. Ammonium tetrafluoroborate in stoichiometric ratio was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran and then PVdF-HFP was added along with continuous stirring till a homogeneous solution is obtained. The homogenous solution thus obtained was poured into polypropylene dishes. Then, the solvent was allowed to evaporate and free-standing films of polymer electrolytes were obtained. These transparent films having thickness ∼100μmwere used for various experimental studies. The ionic conductivity was measured by complex impedance spectroscopy with HP4284A precision LCR meter operating in the 20 Hz to 1 MHz frequency range using a sample holder with silver/platinum electrodes [14, 27, 32–34]. XRD patterns of the polymer electrolyte system were recorded by using Philips analytic X-ray diffractometer with copper as a source of Kα radiation having wavelength 1.54oA.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The variation of conductivity of polymer electrolytes as a function of NH4BF4 concentration is shown in Fig. 1. From Fig. 1, it has been observed that the conductivity increases
initially with an increase in salt concentration, reaches a saturation value, and then shows a small decrease at higher salt concentrations. A maximum conductivity of 3.62 × 10−6 S/cm at room temperature has been obtained at 30 wt% NH4BF4 concentration. At low salt concentrations, the conductivity increases linearly which shows that salt is completely dissociated and nearly all ions are available for conduction. An increase in conductivity of polymer electrolytes with an increase in salt content can be explained by Kohlrausch independent ion rule σ =∑nuze, where n is the number of free mobile ions, u is the mobility of ion, z is the valence order of ionic species, and e is the charge on electron [20, 35]. At medium salt concentrations, the deviation in linearity is observed that can be explained to be due to the formation of ion aggregates, which do not take part in the conduction process. The formation of ion aggregates can be explained by Bjerrum’s law. According to this law, the formation of ion aggregates occurs only if the interionic distance is smaller than q, which is given by q = zizj e2/(8πεoεkT), where z, εo, ε, k, and T represent valence order of ions, dielectric constant of vacuum, dielectric constant of medium, Boltzmann’s constant, and temperature, respectively [36]. At higher salt concentrations, the concentration of free ions decreases due to formation of more ion aggregates, which increases the viscosity and reduces the mobility, and hence, conductivity decreases [31, 37].
The presence of ion aggregates at higher salt concentrations can also be checked qualitatively by Bmass action consideration^ [15]. According to this method, if a graph is plotted between log σ and log C, where σ is the conductivity and C is the concentration of salt, then a linear behavior in the plot shows that all the ions present as free ions and deviation from linearity suggest the presence of ion aggregates in
polymer electrolytes [38–40]. Figure 2 shows the variation of log σ and log C for polymer electrolytes containing PVdFHFP and NH4BF4. In Fig. 2, a linear variation is observed at low salt concentrations, which suggests that all the ions present in the electrolyte are free ions in this concentration range. But at higher salt concentrations, a deviation from the linear behavior is observed, which suggests that ion aggregates are present in this concentration range and these results are in good agreement with the conductivity results given in Fig. 1.
The effect of addition of plasticizer (DMA) on the conductivity behavior was studied for polymer electrolytes containing PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4. At this composition, both undissociated salt and ion aggregates were present. The conductivity of plasticized polymer electrolytes was measured as a function of DMA concentration (wt% of polymer), and the results obtained are shown in Fig. 3. From Fig. 3, it has been observed that the conductivity increases at low concentration of DMA, then reaches a saturation value, and even a small decrease is observed at higher DMA concentrations. The conductivity of polymer electrolytes increases by nearly three orders of magnitude (from 10−6 to 10−3 S/cm) with the addition of DMA, and a maximum conductivity of 1.10 × 10−3 S/ cm at room temperature has been observed at 80 wt% DMA. At low DMA concentration, the rise in conductivity is large, which could be explained to be due to the dissociation of ion aggregates/undissociated salt present in the electrolyte in addition to an increase in the amorphous content. The higher dielectric constant (ε =37.8) of plasticizer assists the dissociation of ion aggregates/undissociated salt and thus increases the concentration of free-moving ions. So, the ions would have a higher tendency of staying free and less probability of association at a given concentration of salt due to higher dielectric constant of plasticizer as described in various
models [17, 20]. The conductivity does not show an increase at the same rate as the plasticizer content is further increased (up to 80 wt%) and reaches a saturation value at higher DMA concentrations. Initially, undissociated salt/ion aggregates get dissociated as the salt concentration in the electrolyte is kept constant (30 wt%), but with an increase in DMA concentration, the amount of undissociated salt/ion aggregates decreases, and hence, the rate of increase in conductivity is not the same and shows a saturation value at higher salt concentrations.
The role of plasticizer in the dissociation of undissociated salt/ion aggregates was also studied by taking fixed amount of DMA in polymer electrolytes with different concentrations of salt (PVdF-HFP + xwt% NH4BF4). These electrolytes contain different concentrations of undissociated salt/ion aggregates. The conductivity of plasticized polymer electrolytes containing a constant concentration of DMA (80 wt% of polymer) as a function of salt concentration was measured, and results are given in Fig. 4. For comparison, the variation of conductivity of unplasticized polymer electrolytes PVdF-HFP + NH4BF4 as a function of salt concentration is also included in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4, it has been observed that the conductivity of plasticized polymer electrolytes is higher than that of unplasticized polymer electrolytes at all salt concentrations, but the increase in conductivity with DMA addition is different at different salt concentration. At low salt concentrations (0–10 wt%), the increase in conductivity with DMA addition is small due to presence of a small amount of undissociated salt and absence of ion aggregates as discussed earlier. The small increase in the conductivity with DMA addition may be due to an increase in amorphous content along with the dissociation of undissociated salt due to an increase in the overall
dielectric constant of the electrolyte. At medium salt concentrations (10–30 wt%), the increase in conductivity with DMA addition is by two orders of magnitude. In this concentration range, both ion aggregates and some undissociated salt shall be present. The addition of plasticizer (DMA) increases the dielectric constant of the electrolyte, which results in the dissociation of ion aggregates and undissociated salt leading to an increase in the number of charge carriers (n), and hence, conductivity increases. At high salt concentrations (30–40 wt%), an increase of conductivity by three orders of magnitude has been observed with DMA addition. This could be explained to be due to the fact that more and more ion aggregates/undissociated salt shall be present and their dissociation where the addition of plasticizer leads to an increase in number of charge carriers, and hence, conductivity increases [17, 31].
The effect of nano-size fumed silica on conductivity of nano-composite unplasticized and plasticized polymer electrolytes has been studied. The variation of conductivity of unplasticized (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4) and plasticized (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt% DMA) polymer electrolyte with the concentration of fumed silica has been given in Fig. 5(a, b). From Fig. 5a, it has been observed that with an increase in concentration of fumed silica, the conductivity of unplasticized polymer electrolytes increases, which is attributed to high defect concentration on the surface of dispersed nano-particles due to the formation of space-charge layers [41–44]. The fumed silica particles are dispersed throughout the polymer electrolyte matrix, and the highly conducting interface layer coatings on the surface of silica
particles overlap on each other resulting into high conducting pathways. Due to the charged surface of fumed silica particles, the NH4
+/H+ ion of NH4BF4 will be attracted towards the oxygen of fumed silica, which shall result in an increase in the dissociation constant of salt. So, the dissociation of undissociated salt/ion aggregates will increase the free ion concentration, and as a result, an increase in conductivity has been observed. However, the extent of conductivity enhancement in composite polymer electrolytes depends on the conductivity of interface layers, dispersoid particle distribution, and the size of particles. The rate of increase in conductivity becomes small at higher concentration of fumed silica, which is due to the blocking effect that hinders the motion of ions [20, 31, 45, 46]. A maximum room temperature conductivity of 8.42 × 10−6 S/cm has been observed at 5 wt% concentration of SiO2 for unplasticized nano-composite electrolytes. From Fig. 5b, it has been observed that the conductivity of plasticized
nano-composite (presence of both plasticizer and fumed silica) polymer electrolytes increases by nearly three orders of magnitude than unplasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes. The presence of DMA mainly enhances the ionic conductivity as explained in Fig. 4, whereas fumed silica improves the mechanical properties of polymer electrolytes. As the salt has fully dissociated in plasticized polymer electrolytes due to high dielectric constant of DMA, so undissociated salt/ion aggregates were not present in these electrolytes. But the increase in conductivity with the addition of fumed silica has been observed, which can be explained due to the formation of high conducting interfacial layer between fumed silica and polymer as discussed above [45–50]. The grain size of fumed silica is quite small (∼7 nm) as compared to the polymer host, the nano-filler able to penetrate into the polymer matrix that promotes the interaction between the plasticizer, fumed silica, and polymer, so the maximum conductivity of 7.20 × 10−3 S/cm is observed at low concentration (3 wt%) of fumed silica.
X-ray diffraction studies of polymer electrolyte system were carried out to study amorphicity/crystallinity of the electrolytes. However, the polymer used in the study is PVdF-HFP, which is highly amorphous (partial crystalline), and as a result, the increase in amorphous content with plasticizer or nano-filler addition shall be relatively small. Figure 6 shows the diffraction spectra of pure PVdF-HFP (a), polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 10
(b), 30 (c) wt% NH4BF4), plasticized polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 40 (d), 80 (e) wt% DMA), and plasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt% DMA + 5 (f) wt% fumed silica). Two small peaks were observed nearly at 2θ = 19° and 21° corresponding to the partial crystalline nature of the polymer [22, Sharma et al. 2016, Role of polymer in enhancement of conductivity of proton and lithium conducting polymer gel electrolytes, submitted]. With the addition of NH4BF4 to PVdF-HFP, the cyrstallinity of the polymer decreases due to complexation of salt and polymer, but the characteristic diffraction peaks of the NH4BF4 now appear nearly at the same position [31]. These peaks indicate that some undissociated salt is present in the polymer electrolytes as discussed in Fig. 1. Overall, no major change has been observed in the spectra as shown in Fig. 6 (b, c) and this could probably be due to the highly amorphous nature of the polymer and appearance of peaks corresponding to salt nearly at the same position. The spectra observed for plasticized polymer elec t ro ly te is s imi lar to that observed for unplasticized (PVdF-HFP) + NH4BF4 polymer electrolyte as shown in Fig. 6 (d, e). A small decrease in the intensity of the peaks has been observed, which can be explained due to a decrease in crystalline content or an increase in amorphous content. It is also accompanied by an increase in conductivity of these polymer electrolytes as discussed in Fig. 3. With the addition of 5 wt% fumed silica to plasticized polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt%DMA), a further decrease in intensity along with some broadening of peaks has been observed in Fig. 6 (f). The decrease in intensity of peaks indicates the dissociation of ion aggregates/undissociated salt present in the electrolytes. Similar results have been reported earlier by different authors [22, 31, Sharma et al. 2016, Role of polymer in enhancement of conductivity of proton and lithium conducting polymer gel electrolytes, submitted]. A small change in amorphous/crystalline phases with the addition of plasticizer and fumed silica has been clearly reflected in the conductivity behavior.
The conductivity of plasticized nano-composite (PVdFHFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt% DMA + 5wt% SiO2) polymer electrolytes has been measured as a function of reciprocal temperature in the 30–130 °C temperature range, and results are given in Fig. 7. For comparison, the variation of conductivity with reciprocal temperature for unplasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 5 wt% SiO2) has also been included in Fig. 7. From
Fig. 7, it has been observed that the conductivity of plasticized nano-composite polymer electrolytes (containing both DMA and fumed silica) is higher than that of unplasticized nanocomposite polymer electrolytes at all temperatures. The curved nature of the plot between log conductivity and
reciprocal temperature for electrolytes indicates the amorphous nature of these electrolytes. The ionic conductivity of electrolyte system increases with an increase in temperature, which is due to the promoted segmental motion of polymer chains by the high temperature. But an increase in conductivity is very small, which shows that these polymer electrolytes are thermally stable in the 30– 130 °C temperature range.
The variation of conductivity of unplasticized nanocomposite (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 5 wt% SiO2) and plasticized nano-composite (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt% DMA + 5 wt% SiO2) polymer electrolytes as a function of time for the period of 30 days has also been measured, and results are given in Fig. 8. No appreciable change in conductivity with time as well as temperature has been observed, which is desirable for their use in practical applications.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
A maximum ionic conductivity of 3.62 × 10−6 S/cm at room temperature has been observed for unplasticized polymer electrolytes containing 30 wt% NH4BF4. Salt is fully dissociated at low concentration, and ion aggregates are formed at higher concentrations of salt, which has been explained on the basis of Bjerrum’s law and Bmass action consideration^. The conductivity of polymer electrolyte has been observed to increase by nearly three orders of magnitude (from 10−6 to 10−3 S/cm)
with the addition of plasticizer, which has been explained to be due to the dissociation of undissociated salt/ion aggregates present in the polymer electrolytes at high concentrations. No major change has been observed in XRD spectra, and this could probably be due to the highly amorphous nature of the polymer. But, a small change in amorphous/crystalline phases with the addition of plasticizer and fumed silica observed in XRD results has been clearly reflected in the conductivity behavior of polymer electrolytes. A maximum conductivity of 1.10 × 10−3 S/cm has been observed for plasticized polymer electrolytes (PVdF-HFP + 30 wt% NH4BF4 + 80 wt% DMA). The conductivity of electrolytes has been increased by adding nano-size fumed silica in unplasticized and plasticized polymer electrolytes along with an improvement in mechanical properties. The variation of conductivity with temperature over the 30–130 °C temperature range and time for a period of 30 days has also been studied and small change in conductivity is observed, which is suitable for their use in practical applications.

metadata.abstractText: Nano-composite polymer electrolytes containing poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVdFHFP), ammonium tetrafluoroborate (NH4BF4), and nano-size fumed silica (SiO2) have been prepared and characterized by complex impedance spectroscopy. Ionic conductivity of polymer has been found to increase with the addition of NH4BF4, and a maximum conductivity of 3.62 × 10 S/cm has been obtained at 30 wt% NH4BF4. The formation of ion aggregates at high concentration of salt has been explained by Bjerrum’s law and mass action considerations. The conductivity of polymer electrolytes has been increased by three orders of magnitude (10 to 10 S/cm) with the addition of plasticizer, and a maximum conductivity of 1.10 × 10 S/cm has been observed at 80 wt%DMA. An increase in conductivity with the addition of nano-size fumed silica is attributed due to the formation of space-charge layers. A maximum conductivity of 7.20 × 10 S/cm has been observed for plasticized nanocomposite polymer electrolytes at 3 wt% SiO2. X-ray diffraction analysis of polymer electrolyte system was also carried out. A small change in conductivity of nano-composite polymer electrolytes observed over the 30–130 °C temperature range and for a period of 30 days is also desirable for their use in various applications.
